datafield.subfield: Hebbian Learning Clustering with Rulkov Neurons

The recent explosion of high dimensional, high resolution ‘big-data’ from automated bioinformatics measurement techniques demands new methods for unsupervised data processing. An essential analysis step is the identification of groups of similar data, or ‘clusters’, in noisy high-dimensional data spaces, as this permits to perform some analysis steps at the group level. Popular clusteringClustering algorithms introduce an undesired cluster shape bias, require prior knowledge of the number of clusters, and are unable to properly deal with noise. Manual data gating, often used to assist these methods, is based on low-dimensional projection techniques, which is prone to obscure the underlying data structure. While Hebbian LearningHebbian learning ClusteringClustering successfully overcomes all of these limitations (by using only local similarities to infer global structure), previous implementations were unsuited to deal with big data sets. Here, we present a novel implementation based on realistic neuronal dynamicsRealistic neuron models that removes also this obstacle. By a performance that scales favourably compared to all standard clusteringClustering algorithms, unbiased large data analysis becomes feasible on standard desktop hardware.
